feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued December 06 at 5:28AM AKST until December 07 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Impactful snowfall possible provided temperatures remain cold enough... A weak front will result in precipitation over the far northern portions of the Panhandle. At present, forecast temperatures in Haines and along the Haines Highway are cold enough to produce 3 to 5 inches of snow. If temperatures are even a few degrees warmer

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued December 05 at 2:03PM AKST until December 07 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: .Warm temperatures have caused ice movement across parts of the Kuskokwim Basin. This has resulted in swiftly moving ice jams and flooding of nearby areas from ice action. ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR AN ICE JAM IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM AKST THURSDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by an ice jam is occurring.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued December 06 at 8:43AM EST until further notice by NWS
entry.summary: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida... St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties. .The Saint Johns River at Astor remains in Minor Flood stage. It is forecast to continue a very slow fall while remaining within Minor Flood stage for the foreseeable future. Residents and interests along the river will continue to see Minor flood impacts.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued December 06 at 9:32AM CST until December 07 at 1:30PM CST by NWS
entry.summary: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Tennessee...Georgia... Lookout Creek near New England affecting Dade and Hamilton Counties. For the Lookout Creek...including New England, Flintstone...Minor flooding is forecast.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 06 at 11:10AM MST until December 08 at 6:00AM MST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO 6 AM MST THURSDAY ABOVE 8000 FEET... * WHAT...Snow above 8000 feet. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 10 inches with locally higher amounts possible. * WHERE...La Sal and Abajo Mountains. * WHEN...From midnight Tuesday night to 6 AM MST Thursday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 06 at 9:10AM MST by NWS
entry.summary: Winds will be between 40 to 45 mph across the wind prone areas this morning. Some periodic gusts up to 60 mph can be expected over the next several hours. These winds may cause some patchy areas of blowing snow over the I-80 summit.
